1451301249094127617.text: & all of this is in addition to $108 million in congressionally directed spending requests that would directly benefit NH communities. I’ll keep working cross the aisle to advance all of these priorities through Congress & deliver this legislation to the President’s desk.

1451301245927534595.text: ✅ $770M for PFAS investigation, testing, remediation & disposal on & around U.S. military installations, including $494M for the Air Force, $167M for the Navy & $98M for the Army. I also fought for an additional $15M to continue the PFAS health impact study I established.

1451301243155058693.text: ✅ $500M for the Title X Family Planning program, a $214 million increase over last year’s funding level. The Title X program provides critical funding for preventative and primary health care services across the country, including in NH.

1451301240420421633.text: ✅ $2.8B in increased funding for key federal child care and early learning programs, including $7.3 billion for Child Care and Development Block Grants to states, as well as $12B for Head Start programs.

1451301237362774019.text: ✅ $370M for the Assistance to Firefighters Grant (AFG) program. The AFG program has long been a top priority for me and provides direct financial assistance to eligible fire departments in order to enhance the safety of firefighters and the public.

1451301234435104769.text: ✅ $20M for a new Cyber Response and Recovery Fund to provide assistance to state & local governments in the aftermath of cyber attacks. State and local governments have increasingly been targeted by malicious actors seeking to disrupt operations and secure a ransom.

1451301231507484684.text: ✅ $20 million for continued submarine workforce training and $130 million to support submarine suppliers, including 40 companies in NH to ensure the Granite State remains a critical contributor to current and next-generation submarine programs.

1451301228672167949.text: ✅ $475M for the Multi-Mission Dry Dock project at the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard to ensure the Shipyard can carry out its missions & continue to strengthen NH’s role in support of our national defense.

1451301225866092546.text: ✅ $25M in housing assistance for Granite Staters and Americans across the country who are in recovery due to substance misuse.

1451301223076872202.text: ✅ The legislation also continues to provide flexibility provisions I authored that allows for SOR grant dollars to be used to support treatment and recovery for cocaine & methamphetamine misuse, in addition to opioid misuse.

1451301220363157508.text: ✅ $2 billion in State Opioid Response grant funding, a $500M increase (!) over FY21, as well as the continuing of a 15 percent set-aside of those funds for hardest hit states, like NH, with the highest opioid overdose death rates.

1451301217301417988.text: ✅ $283M for State & Local Law Assistance and COPS Office grant programs to improve police-community relations. This is an 84% increase in funding & will support programs on de-escalation, implicit bias, crisis intervention & training.

1451301212230463493.text: ✅ $615M to help communities & first responders address the substance use disorder epidemic, including opioid & drug trafficking. This is $73.5M above last year's funding levels & includes funds that invest in drug, mental health & vet treatment courts and SUD treatment programs.

1451301208841494534.text: ✅ The highest level *ever* for the Office on Violence Against Women, which is an increase of $265.5M above FY21 funding levels. It also boosts funds for Juvenile Justice programs by 37%. These programs support youth & provide an alternative to detention & delinquency prevention.

1375544627143532544.text: The stories go on & highlight why the ACA has been such a consequential step forward for so many Granite Staters & Americans. But our work isn't over – I'll continue to fight to expand access to quality, affordable health care that all Americans deserve.

1375544625839095809.text: As a college student, Tiffany from Dover struggled to afford the costs of treatment & care for her autoimmune disorder. Though she had health insurance, it was the norm for companies to deny care or increase costs for Americans w/pre-existing conditions. The ACA changed that.

1375544624660541440.text: James from Keene & his wife lost their health insurance after she was laid off – making a stressful situation even worse. The ACA helps Americans when they need a hand because cost should never be a barrier to care, & allowed this couple to #GetCovered thru the ACA Marketplace.

1375544623616176131.text: Christine from Goffstown had left her job and with it, her employer-sponsored health care plan. To make matters worse, the high cost of COBRA made paying to stay on her old plan out of the question. The ACA opened up options that she wouldn’t have been able to afford otherwise.

1375544622483697664.text: David from Merrimack is a proud dad who wants the best for his kids. When his son graduated from college amid an economic downturn, David was worried he'd be left without health insurance. Thanks to the ACA, Americans under 26 like David’s son can stay on their parents’ plan.

1375544621447663627.text: This week, we celebrated the 11th anniversary of the ACA, legislation that changed the way we view health care in the U.S. – as a right, not a privilege. To mark the occasion, I want to share some of the stories I've heard from Granite Staters on what the ACA means for them.

1321108768676057089.text: All the while, NH families are struggling to pay the bills, small businesses have gone & hospitals are in dire financial straits as they treat a new surge in COVID-19 patients. There is still no comprehensive national plan for testing, contact tracing & PPE delivery.
